content.question: A curve is defined by the parametric functions <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="the derivative of x, with respect to t, is not equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2 x of t, minus y of t, equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for all <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following equals <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.1: (BC ONLY) Defining and Differentiating Parametric Equations

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
